description: Erection of single storey rear extension with 6x roof lights
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

---OFFICER REPORT---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwellingProposalThe application seeks the erection of a single storey side extension, a first floor side extension, a single storey rear extension and a front porch.The application is a revision of refused application 21/00830/HOU.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers; and,- Car parking.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers are satisfied that the proposed front porch, single storey side extension and single storey rear extension would appear as subordinate and proportionate additions to the dwelling. Their design would be in keeping with that of the existing building and they would not significantly disrupt the sense of symmetry with the adjoining semi-detached property. Officers consider that they would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.The previous proposal for the site was refused because it would have resulted in the loss of the existing cat-slide roof and would have disrupted the symmetry with the adjoining semi-detached neighbour. In this revised application, the first floor side extension has been set back by approximately 750mm, such that the appearance of the cat-slide roof would be preserved. The proposed extension would not replicate the existing extension at the adjoining semi-detached neighbour, but because it would now be set back, the symmetry of the original facade would be maintained. Officers therefore consider that the proposed development would not have any material adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers are satisfied that the scale and siting of the proposed extensions would be such that they would not appear overbearing or unduly deprive neighbouring occupiers of natural light. The proposed windows at first floor level in the southern flank elevation may give rise to unacceptable views over neighbouring properties but this could be effectively mitigated by a condition requiring obscure glazing. The remaining windows would offer similar views to the existing.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Car ParkingPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals. Where provided, each motorcycle parking space should count towards the maximum for car parking spaces at all use classes.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.The proposed development would result in the loss of one off-street car parking space (within the existing garage). This is considered to be an improvement on the existing situation, since the property currently benefits from four car parking spaces, which is above the maximum level of one space set by policy T6.1 of the London Plan 2021.ConclusionThe proposed development would reduce the number of off-street car parking spaces on the site, which would, in turn, help to promote sustainable modes of transport. This is a benefit which carries significant weight in favour of the proposal.The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area and on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable. This is a neutral matter.Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Background PapersIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal---END OF OFFICER REPORT---
